<!-- Subheading: Project Overview -->
<h3 style="font-size: 1.5em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 20px; color: #001731; text-align: center;">PROJECT OVERVIEW</h3>

::: {style="display: flex; gap: 20px; max-width: 1200px; margin: 0 auto;"}

<!-- Left Column -->
::: {style="flex: 1; max-width: 50%;"}

<span style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731;">CLIENT</span>  
Paleobiology Database  

<br>

<span style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731;">GOAL</span>  
Develop a predictive model that forecasts the prevalence of marine mammal fossils across the globe.  

<br>

<span style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731;">PRIMARY TOOLS</span>  
R & RStudio, GIS, Adobe Creative Suite 

<br>

<span style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731;">BACKGROUND</span>  
The client is a non-governmental non-profit public resource for paleontological data. Their mission is to encourage and enable data-driven collaborative efforts that address large-scale paleobiological questions. The client requests a way to predict potential fossil localities to discover new fossils.  

<br>

<span style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731;">PRODUCT</span>  
Our team developed a predictive model using marine mammals as study organisms. The model uses the geospatial coordinates of all known marine mammal fossils and identifies key geographic, environmental, and socioeconomic predictors of fossil localities. The model successfully forecasts locations with a high probability of yielding new fossil discoveries.  

:::

<!-- Details: Challenges and Solutions -->
<h3 style="font-size: 1.5em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 20px; color: #001731; text-align: center;">CHALLENGES AND SOLUTIONS</h3>

<!-- Dropdown Section -->
<details style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
  <summary style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731; cursor: pointer; padding: 10px; background-color: #f7f7f7; border-radius: 5px;">
    DIFFERENT ORGANISMS
  </summary>
  <p style="margin: 10px 20px; font-size: 1em; color: black;">
    <b>The Challenge</b>: different groups of organisms have their distributions influenced by completely different factors.  <br> <br>
    <b>The Solution</b>: develop independent models based on organisms with similar ecologies and geographic distributions to avoid homogeneity of the model.
  </p>
</details>

<details style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
  <summary style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731; cursor: pointer; padding: 10px; background-color: #f7f7f7; border-radius: 5px;">
    INHERENT BIAS
  </summary>
  <p style="margin: 10px 20px; font-size: 1em; color: black;">
    <b>The Challenge</b>: fossil distribution is heavily biased by socioeconomic factors, such as GDP, which do not reflect a true biological or geologic signal. <br> <br>
    <b>The Solution</b>: standardize the dataset for GDP and other socioeconomic factors to avoid implicit Northern Hemisphere bias.
  </p>
</details>

<!-- Details: Next Steps -->
<h3 style="font-size: 1.5em; font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 20px; color: #001731; text-align: center;">NEXT STEPS</h3>
<p style="margin: 10px 20px; font-size: 1em; color: black;">
    Now that we've delivered the model to the client, what's next? 
  </p>

<!-- Dropdown Section -->
<details style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
  <summary style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731; cursor: pointer; padding: 10px; background-color: #f7f7f7; border-radius: 5px;">
    EXPAND THE SCOPE
  </summary>
  <p style="margin: 10px 20px; font-size: 1em; color: black;">
   Marine mammals were an ideal starting point because their distribution is easily modeled to modern coastlines. Now, we can expand to other fossil groups, including terrestrial organisms.
  </p>
</details>

<details style="margin-bottom: 20px;">
  <summary style="font-size: 1.2em; font-weight: bold; color: #001731; cursor: pointer; padding: 10px; background-color: #f7f7f7; border-radius: 5px;">
    UNITE DATASETS
  </summary>
  <p style="margin: 10px 20px; font-size: 1em; color: black;">
    The dstribution of fossils is just the first step. A major factor is being able to excavate fossils is the surface exposure of the bedrock. By combinind our model with geologic maps from the USGS, we'll be able to forecast high value localities for paleontologists to prospect. 
  </p>
</details>
